This is for a character in my fanfic, dropped into NwN as close as possible, so I've got loads of back-story, but that can wait until we see whether it's worth it. Suffice to say, she was raised a weak little oddball in a clan of barbarians, but turned out to be a deadshot with a bow and cheerleader for the raids.

In fact, here's the first time we meet her - and her first, hesitant kill...
Spoiler"Glimmer." She prised one eye open. A slit of stabbing, sickening brightness. "Come back." She pushed the spit-wet dowel out of her mouth with her tongue and croaked the one word she could think of. "Shit." "There's my girl!" Yull squatted beside her, necklace of runes and bones dangling, grinning that twisted grin that showed the hole in his teeth and offered no help at all. "What did you see?" Glimmer heaved one hand up to grip her head. Felt like if she didn't hold her skull together it would burst. Shapes still fizzed on the inside of her lids, like the glowing smears when you've looked at the sun. "I saw folk falling from a high tower. Dozens of 'em." She winced at the thought of them hitting the ground. "I saw folk hanged. Rows of 'em." Her gut cramped at the memory of swinging bodies, dangling feet. "I saw...a battle, maybe? Below a purple hill." Yull sniffed. "This is the north. Takes no magic to see a battle coming. What else?" "I saw Ustred burning." Glimmer could almost smell the smoke still. She pressed her hand to her left eye. Felt hot. Burning hot... ..."What does it mean?" Yull held a fingertip to his scarred lips, the way he did when he was on the verge of deep pronouncements. "No bloody idea. Mayhap the turning of time's wheel shall unlock the secrets of these visions." Glimmer spat, but her mouth still tasted like despair. "So...wait and see, then." "Eleven times out of twelve that's the best course." Yull scratched at his collarbone and winked. "But if I said it that way no one would reckon me a deep thinker." "Well, I can unveil two secrets right away." Glimmer groaned as she pushed herself up onto one elbow. "My head hurts and I shat myself." "That second one's no secret, anyone with a nose is party to it." "My thanks for that." "No bother."... ..."So...you really think I've got the Eye?" Yull strode on through the woods with that loping gait that, however fast Glimmer walked, always left her an uncomfortable half-step behind. "You think I'd be pissing my efforts away on you otherwise?" Glimmer sighed. "S'pose not. Just, in the songs, it's a thing witches and magi and deep-wise folk use to see into the fog of what comes. Not a thing that makes idiots fall down and shit themselves." "In case you never noticed, bards have a habit of dressing things up. There is a fine living to be made, d'you see, in songs about deep-wise witches, but in shitty idiots, less." Glimmer sadly conceded the truth of that... ...Yull stopped dead, tattooed hand raised and eyes narrowed. All Glimmer could hear was whispering branches, the tap of drips from the melting snow, the tweet of birds in the budding trees. Glimmer leaned towards him. "What's the -" "Nock a shaft to your bow and keep 'em talking," whispered Yull. "Who?" "Failing that, sing 'em a song. You're blessed with a fine voice." And he darted off the road and into the trees. "A song?" hissed Glimmer, but Yull's flitting shadow had already vanished into the brush. That was when she heard a man's voice. "Sure this is the way?" She'd had her bow over her shoulder, hoping for a deer, and now she shrugged it off, fumbled out an arrow and nearly dropped it, managed to get it nocked in spite of a flurry of nervy twitches up her arm. "We was told to check the woods." A deeper, harder, scarier voice. "Do these look like woods?" An old man came around the bend in the road. He held a staff in his hand, and he lowered it, metal gleaming in the dappled light, and Glimmer realized it weren't a staff but a spear. There were three of them. The old one had a sorry look, like none of this was his idea. Next came a nervous lad with a shield and a short axe. Finally, there was a big man with a heavy beard and a heavier frown. Glimmer didn't like the look of him at all. Her mother always said not to point arrows at folk unless you meant to see 'em dead, so she drew her bow halfway and pointed it at the road. "Best hold still," she said. The old one stared at her. "Girl, you have a ring through your nose." "I am aware." And Glimmer stuck her tongue out and touched the tip to it. "It keeps me tethered." "You might wander off?" "My thoughts might." "Is it gold?" asked the lad. "Bronze," she lied, since gold was apt to turn unpleasant meetings into lethal ones. "And the paint?" "The mark of the cross is a goodly mark much loved by the moon. The Eye is the left eye and the cross will keep it's sight true through the fog of what comes." She turned her head and spat without taking her eyes off them, then added, "Maybe," since she wasn't sure the cross had done a thing but get smeared on her pillow when she forgot to wipe it off of a night. She wasn't the only doubter. "You mad?" growled the big man. Glimmer sighed. Far from the first time she'd fielded that question. "One person's mad is another's remarkable." "Be a fine thing if you were to put that bow down," said the old one. "I like it where it is." Though she definitely didn't. It was getting all sticky in her hand, shoulder aching from the effort of holding it half-drawn, and a twitch in her neck starting up that she worried might jerk the string loose. "What you doing down here?" "Putting an end to Dyse and her arse-lickers, and bringing Ustred back into Inith where it belongs." Glimmer's knuckles whitened around her bow, fear turning to anger. "You are fucking not." "Already happening." The old man shrugged. "Only question for you is whether you'll be raised up with the winners or slung in the body-pit with the losers." "She is bloody mad." The big one stepped forwards. "Now drop the -" And he made this long wheeze, and his shirt stuck out, a glint of metal showing. "Oh," he said, dropping to his knees. The lad turned around. Glimmer's arrow stuck into his back, just under his shoulder-blade. Her turn to say, "Oh," not sure whether she'd meant to let go the string or not. A flash of metal and the old man's head jolted, the blade of Yull's sword catching him in the throat. He dropped his spear, grabbed for him with clumsy fingers. "Hush, now." Yull slapped his hand away and ripped the blade free in a red gout. He wriggled on the ground, fiddling with the great wound in his neck as if he might stop it spurting. He was trying to say something, but as fast as he could spit the blood out his mouth filled again. Then he stopped moving. "You killed 'em." Glimmer felt all hot. There were some red specks on her hand. The big one was lying on his face, shirt soaked dark. "To be fair, you killed this one," said Yull. The lad knelt there, making little squeaky gasps. Yull leaned down and calmly plucked the knife from the lad's belt. "Was hoping to set him a question or two, but he'll be giving no answers with that shaft in his lung." As if to prove the point, he coughed some blood into his hand and stared over it at Glimmer. He looked a bit offended, like she'd said something hurtful. "Still, no one ever gets things all their own way." Glimmer jumped at the crack as Yull rammed the lad's knife into the crown of his head. His eyes rolled up and his back arched, then he fell on his side. "They didn't seem so bad," Glimmer said. "For a girl struggling to penetrate the mists of the future, you don't half miss what's right in front of you." Yull was already rooting through the old man's pockets. "If you wait 'til they seem bad, you've waited way too long."

Do please have a look, and let me know your thoughts.

EDIT 2: Included a full skill schedule, now I've had the chance to play her. Without over-blowing my own trumpet (I hope), she does play really well and pretty easily, even at lower levels, which is why I'm moving her to the Full Epic forum. I opted for Spellcraft to cover the "spare" skill points, as much as anything because I had easy access to helpful Rogues, but if you want to solo her you might want to swap that for some cross-classed skills in Disable Trap, Open Lock, and Search (Set Trap, too, if you find you have points to spare). It might be worth noting that in Aielund (where she was tested), Bard receives an additional 2 skill points p/level and the Song is altered. I chose to ignore these during my playthrough, as it would be an illegal build elsewhere. Comparative builds are detailed further down in the thread, but I believe Glimmer stands well enough to be distinct from them.

Other than that, looks pretty solid.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I like this build. It looks like something I might have conjured up myself, only I never did - unfortunately.
Barbarian has several things to offer an archer with UD, 10% speed advantage, martial weapons (for HE builds) and a full BAB class from the start. You even get to boost the mighty property now and then with rage.
I have used barbarian from time to time and posted a Bb/Wi/AA build in the 20s section. I also found a couple of barbarian/bard archer builds in my folders, among them a Bb8 Ba3 AA29.  It is based on much the same principles as your build, only with more brawn and less song. It even has the same starting and ending abilities.
With the relatively high AB of a low level high dexterity archer, I often take rapid shot before weapon focus longbow. The order in which I take blind fight, called shot and improved critical depends on the setting. If there is speed enhancing options, called shot comes late. If there are a lot of concealed enemies, BF comes in time before they start to appear. And I like improved critical as soon as possible. Those juicy x3 crits cannot come too often.
I also like to take AS and EP sooner and rather take great dex later, unless I build up dex for ED. The thinking is that AS + EP = +1 AB +2AC, whereas 2x great dex = +1 AB +1 AC. But then again dex also works on skills and reflex save.
But these are all minor things and your build is indeed good as is.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, Mick, it means a lot. And thanks also for the links, which I can now access - hoorah!

As far as the feats are concerned, I confess to a little coin-tossing between when to take Imp Crit and Called Shot (CS won), though on reflection I think I now prefer earlier IC. Probably a personal thing, but I like getting Blind Fight early on, just in case. Taking the WF before Rapid Shot is a hangover from lots of OC playing, when you get your first enhanced weapon at around level 4/5 (if you do the prison first), and you get what you've focused in. So, mostly practical in nature. I decided to take Weapon Finesse rather than Toughness or Epic Will (my old desire for saves over 20), because if I should get trapped into melee (heavens forbid) I'd like a reasonable chance of breaking free. I do like what you say about Armor Skin and Epic Prowess, and will steal that!

Looking at the other builds, it's interesting that more levels of Bb are often taken, whereas my initial thought was for a Barb 2/ Bard 16/ AA 22 to hit the "sweet 16" (TM M Dagger) of song, for better party support, but I was lured away by better enchanted arrows and the AA bonus feat at L26.

All good stuff!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: All three classes have something to offer if taken enough levels. Bard for song, spells and frequent skill drops, barbarian for TR and AA for more AB and damage. So there are indeed different ways to build with them. I even found a strength based TR archer with dev crit longbow among my Bb Ba AA builds, but I believe strength based archers in general are better with fighter or RDD.
